titles.title: Rokushin Gattai GodMars
Six God Combination God Mars
God Mars
六神合体ゴッドマーズ
God Mars

relatedanime.anime: Rokushin Gattai GodMars: Juunanasai no Densetsu

anime.description: A.D. 1982, the planet alignment brought the human beings ordeal we should overcome, and it caused a convulsion on the Earth. During the conflict, a light fell on to the Myojinsho reef, and five lights scattered around the Earth as if they followed it. 17 years had passed since then. A.D. 1999, human beings had developed all of the solar system, and began to embark for outer space. The Earth Defense Army organized an elite squad, Crasher, to provide for various happening in space. Myojin Takeru was the member of the team. He was found in the light fell on to the Myojinsho reef. Actually he was Mars who was born on the planet Gishin. When he grew up, he heard unearthly voice: "Mars, stop the Earthians` advancement to the space. Explode the Earth." He was a living triggering device that had been sent by Emperor Zure, who plotted to conquer the universe. However, Mars, who had been raised as an Earthian, rejected the order, and made up his mind to face the severe fate. Source: AnimeNfo

tag.name: shounen
tag.description: In the context of manga and associated media, shounen, literally meaning "youth" and often also specifically "boy", refers to a male audience roughly between the ages of 10 and 18. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: extrasensory perception
tag.description: Extrasensory perception (ESP), involves reception of information not gained through the recognized physical senses but sensed with the mind. The term was coined by Sir Richard Burton, and adopted by Duke University psychologist J. B. Rhine to denote psychic abilities such as telepathy and clairvoyance, and their trans-temporal operation as precognition or retrocognition. ESP is also sometimes casually referred to as a sixth sense, gut instinct or hunch, which are historical English idioms. The term implies acquisition of information by means external to the basic limiting assumptions of science, such as that organisms can only receive information from the past to the present. In Japanese usage the term is often misappropriated to refer to any supernatural, non-magical, super power. Users of such powers are called `esper` in Japanese. The term `esper` is not normally in use outside of Japan but is slowly being introduced due to its usage in anime and manga. In anime/manga the following powers, among others, are described as ESP: - telepathy - precognition - clairvoyance - retrocognition - remote viewing - aura reading - out-of-body experiences (OBE) - psychokinesis

tag.name: robot
tag.description: A robot is an automatically guided machine, able to do tasks on its own. Another common characteristic is that by its appearance or movements, a robot often conveys a sense that it has intent or agency of its own. Not to be confused with android (human-like robot).

tag.name: dynamic
tag.description: Some of the central structural elements in anime are: Plot Continuity How does the plot or several plots unfold. Are they a strictly linear retelling of one big continuing story, a serial, possibly with several side stories, or is the content chopped into a set of unconnected episodes, only sharing the same setting and characters? Stereotype Characters Then there is the question of the character set presentation. Is it completely original, or is it your usual stereotypical character cast. Both choices have their merit, for example it would not really make much sense to reinvent the wheel for a harem anime. Fans of that genre come to expect their favourite stereotype protagonists. Plot Twists Finally there is the question of how complex the plot / the story unfolds. Are there side-plots that merge into the main plot leading to unexpected plot twists, or is the anime quite predictable? The latter would not be appropriate for detective stories. In harem anime on the other hand a foreseeable outcome is actually something the fans will come to expect.

tag.name: target audience
tag.description: Anime, like everything else in the modern world, is targeted towards specific audiences, both implicitly by the creators and overtly by the marketing. While categories are associated with specific sex and age groups, this is not a bar on the anime being enjoyed by people who don`t fit into that band; not only do crossover titles exist, but the categories also have a considerable following outside their main demographic, and a person might as well enjoy anime from all categories. Still, does not invalidate the usefulness of marking a title as one of the categories; the same themes will likely be treated differently in anime geared for different audiences. Only one should not jump the gun and assume that a title will be more or less serious or present content in this or that way due to its target audience, or conversely assume the target audience on the content and its presentation alone. As such, the audience categories help form a broad impression of how a title might work with the announced themes, but offer little to no in-depth information about specific content or its treatment. The audience categories originate from manga magazines, which group titles of a same intended audience into a magazine that is advertised as belonging to that category, and so manga-based anime will have the category from their parent work. As for anime based on other works, the audience is often debatable, but comparing information such as time slot to the manga-based anime generally helps figure out the most likely possibility. If the parent material was classified under multiple audiences over time (for example, it was originally shounen, but then as the plot changed and became more mature, it was reclassified as seinen), and the anime adapts parent material time periods covering multiple audiences, we tag all audiences covered by the anime adaptation.

tag.name: original work
tag.description: What the anime is based on! This is given as the original work credit in the OP. Mostly of academic interest, but a useful bit of info, hinting at the possible depth of story.

tag.name: setting
tag.description: The setting describes in what time and place an anime takes place. To a certain extent it describes what you can expect from the world in the anime.

tag.name: elements
tag.description: Next to Themes setting the backdrop for the protagonists in anime, there are the more detailed plot Elements that centre on character interactions: "What do characters do to each other or what is done to them?". Is it violent Action, an awe-inspiring Adventure in a foreign place, the gripping life of a Detective, a slapstick Comedy, an Ecchi Harem anime, a SciFi epic, or some Fantasy travelling adventure?

tag.name: place
tag.description: The places the anime can take place in. Includes more specific places such as a country on Earth, as well as more general places such as a dystopia or a mirror world.

tag.name: calling your attacks
tag.description: "GIGAAAAAA DRIIIIIILLL BREAKEEEEEERRR" If you can do something more impressive than just throw a punch, your attack(s) must have an equally impressive name. More than that, you have to call it out as you launch the attack. It doesn`t matter if it`s a martial arts move, a magical spell or your secret superweapon, if you can`t say its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Having a special attack is always a must, but not impressive enough. Every special attack needs a name. A really awesome and outstanding name which is easy to remember and even easier and impressive to yell. Because it just is not enough to name your attack. No, to unleash the full power of your attack, you have to call its name in your most MANLY and LOUDEST voice. It does not matter whether it is a martial arts move, a magical spell or flying drills from your mecha, if you can`t call its name, it just isn`t nearly as cool or effective. Not a requirement but wearing shades while calling your attack makes it at least twice as cool, moreover giving your mecha or magical companion shades too results in an immeasurable level of awesomeness, bringing down every enemy just through the POWER OF YOUR VOICE. A standard feature of practically every mecha, mahou shoujo, high fantasy, or martial arts anime. [Source: TV Tropes]

tag.name: super power
tag.description: Be it an ancient Greek Heracles, a cybernetic muscle-man, or a fourteen year-old girl in a mini-skirted sailor suit. As long as they have super powers, they`re in the show.

tag.name: space
tag.description: The final frontier.

tag.name: mecha
tag.description: Mecha in Japanese basically means mechanical things; everything from an electric whisk or a car to a spaceship or a robot. Here however we limit it to the more exotic things usually referred to as mecha anime: robots, whether controlled by a human or not, and their ilk. See Androids, Piloted Robots, Power Suits, Robot Helpers, Transforming Robots for a more specific classification.

tag.name: transforming craft
tag.description: A transforming craft is an object built by humans or other intelligent lifeforms, usually a robot but sometimes also a vehicle of some sort, that can rearrange its parts in order to switch between a minimum of two forms.

tag.name: plot continuity
tag.description: Consistency of the characteristics of persons, plot, objects, places and events seen by the viewer. A single linear focused plot is highly continuous. A truly random plot is highly discontinuous.

tag.name: manga
tag.description: Manga is the lifeblood that drives the anime industry. Everything and its mother is based on manga. However! There are exceptions where the manga was not the basis for the anime. It`s common practice to make manga adaptations of many popular anime, there`s a manga based on Evangelion, and two (one shounen and one shoujo) based on each of Escaflowne and Mahou Tsukai Tai. Also it`s quite common to release manga and anime versions of a story in parallel, for instance Nadesico and Shoujo Kakumei Utena. There are also cases where an anime continues in a manga, as in the case of Angel Beats! and Angel Beats: Heaven`s Door, or reverse. See also http://anidb.net/t6493 [manhua] and http://anidb.net/t5010 [manhwa].

tag.name: action
tag.description: Action anime usually involve a fairly straightforward story of good guys versus bad guys, where most disputes are resolved by using physical force. It often contains a lot of shooting, explosions and fighting.

tag.name: science fiction
tag.description: Science fiction stories usually focus on how situations could be different in the future when we are more technologically advanced; due to either our own achievements or having met with other civilizations whom we have learned from.

tag.name: tragedy
tag.description: Tragedy is a form of drama characterized by seriousness and dignity, usually involving a conflict between a character and some higher power, such as the law, the gods, fate, or society.

tag.name: unsorted
tag.description: a bunch of tags that still need to be either deleted or moved into proper places.

tag.name: super robot
tag.description: These robots tend to have almost semi-magical attacks, which seem impossible or non-realistic, and/or perform non-realistic transformation sequences where they seem to gain/lose mass and utterly change their form, even if it means making their super-hard armour bend like plastic sheets.

tag.name: space pirates
tag.description: Depending how you view the future, lawlessness will always be present in society. There`s always going to be a shadier, nastier way of doing business, and that will almost certainly follow humanity to the stars. Thus, sci-fi authors will include Expies of modern and historic (un)organized crime—be they space mafia, gangs, or—in our case—pirates. It`s not as anachronistic as it might seem. After all, pirates themselves have made a Real Life comeback in Somalia, and it`s a lucrative enough "business" that it`s taken a multinational military response to fight back. Surely an established society in outer space with significant trade and commerce would suffer similar problems! ... Well, maybe. The major problem with space pirates preying on space commerce is that space is vast. The challenge of catching commercial shipping in open space is orders of magnitudes more difficult than catching them on the open seas. Sometimes, this is cleverly worked around and justified. Most of the time, however, it isn`t. There are two kinds of Space Pirates in science fiction. The normal version are violent criminals with a spaceship, who attack other spaceships, just like present-day pirates. Once you have shipping between different solar systems/planets, pirates preying on said shipping are bound to show. Simple as that. Done this way, piracy actually makes sense, provided there`s an enabling factor. That could be anything from the technology of the setting creating trade lanes (via a Portal Network, predictable Faster Than Light Travel routes thanks to Negative Space Wedgies, or timed space flights between planets to reduce time spent between planets, as in Real Life), to using a variant of the method employed by modern pirates (say, smaller ships striking at commercial shipping in the orbit of a planet). The other version does a Recycled In SPACE on every eighteenth century pirate cliche ever. Reasons for including this version will typically be along the lines of "Because Space Is An Ocean, it has to have Pirates" rather than making any meaningful attempt at justifying their existence. They have Cornish accents, beards, say "Arr!" a lot, have parrots (probably robot) and false limbs (probably cybernetic) and wear tricorn hats and eyepatches (or have cybernetic eyes). They may even have ships shaped like boats. One of the best known space pirates is http://anidb.net/ch2087 [Captain Harlock] from the same named popular http://anidb.net/a725 [TV anime series]. Source: TV Tropes

tag.name: recycled animation -- TO BE SPLIT AND DELETED
tag.description: This tag overlaps recaps, http://anidb.net/t4299 [flashbacks], and http://anidb.net/t3671 [footage reuse]. For that reason, it is set to be split. If you can, please apply the correct tag to the anime that have it, and remove this one from them; guidance on how to use each of those tags can be found in their description. If what the anime contains is a mere recap, please don`t apply any tag at all, and remove this tag from it instead.

tag.name: daikaijuu
tag.description: Literally translating to giant monster, daikaiju is an element found often in Japanese entertainment. Although usually for the science fiction genre it is also often used in horror, fantasy, mecha, and to a lesser extent comedy. Any monster that towers over a house technically qualifies as a daikaiju. Some anime, usually mecha, will go as far as calling their daikaiju with a specific title.

tag.name: gattai
tag.description: Gattai is when two fighting spirits collide and unite, when a man`s soul is ablaze! When you are about to get your asses kicked by the big bad evil, it`s time to show your true fighting spirit and gattai, literally combine with your mecha to become at least ten times as powerful and kick the big bad evil`s ass.

tag.name: sense of foreboding
tag.description: The anime starts off quietly, everything seems to be fine, but from episode to episode the signs that something ominous is about to happen increase. E.g. a typical mystery setting.

tag.name: happy ending
tag.description: And they lived "happily ever after"... *sniff*. All issues in the anime have been resolved, the love polygons sorted out, the conflicts resolved, the guy gets the girl (or the other way around), and everyone else lives on blissfully. (Not very realistic, but then again this is anime.)

tag.name: monster of the week
tag.description: On a pretty much regular basis — weekly or episodic — the protagonists engage in some kind of conflict. This can be an actual showdown between mecha, or the all-out fight against an enemy, or a (car) race that needs to be won. This can make the anime quite repetitive.

tag.name: technical aspects
tag.description: It may sometimes be useful to know about technical aspects of a show, such as information about its broadcasting or censorship. Such information can be found here.

tag.name: multi-anime projects
tag.description: Many anime are created as part of larger projects encompassing many shows without direct relation to one another. Normally, there is a specific idea in mind: for example, the http://anidb.net/t4859 [Young Animator Training Project] aims to stimulate the on-the-job training of next-generation professionals of the anime industry, whereas the http://anidb.net/t3763 [World Masterpiece Theatre] aims to animate classical stories from all over the world.

tag.name: ending
tag.description: This is a container tag to house meta-like tags relating to how endings of anime play out.

tag.name: speculative fiction
tag.description: Speculative fiction is an umbrella genre encompassing fiction with certain elements that do not exist in the real world, often in the context of supernatural, futuristic or other imaginative themes. This includes, but is not limited to, science fiction, fantasy, superhero fiction, horror, utopian and dystopian fiction, fairytale fantasy, supernatural fiction, as well as combinations thereof. Source: Wikipedia

tag.name: Super Robot Wars
tag.description: Super Robot Wars is a series of tactical role-playing video games produced by Banpresto. The main feature of the franchise is having a story that crosses over several popular mecha anime, manga and video games, allowing characters and mecha from different titles to team up or battle one another. Due to the nature of crossover games and licensing involved, only a few games have been released outside Japan, and in English; early English-language games only feature Banpresto`s original characters and mecha, and a flagship installment were to never be released until 2016, with the English release of Super Robot Wars V in Southeast Asian countries. The franchise celebrated its 25th anniversary in 2016. Source: Wikipedia

episode.title: オレはだれだ!?
Who am i?
episode.summary: Takeru Myojin is visited by the evil Emperor Zule of Planet Gishin, who claims to be his father in his dreams. In his dream, Emperor Zule reveals Takeru was sent to Earth to destroy it, but Takeru rejects his orders and brushes it off as just a dream. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: でた! 脅威の六神合体
There! The threatening six gods unite
episode.summary: To find out the truth, Takeru visits his parents’ home. There, his father, Professor Myojin reveals Takeru is not his biological son. Suddenly, his parents’ home comes under attack by another assassin from Planet Gishin, who possesses Esper powers. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: おそるべき秘密
The horrible secret
episode.summary: After analyzing Gaia’s command capsule, Commissioner Otsuka discovers its secret. While the other Crasher Squad members leave for battle, Takeru is ordered to stay behind and is kept in confinement. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 孤独な超人タケル
The Lonely Superman, Takeru
episode.summary: The other Crasher Squad members are suspicious of Takeru, due to his Esper power and mysterious ability to control Gaia. Now, Takeru must face the Gishin assassin alone. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: さらば! 愛する地球よ
Goodbye, Dear Earth
episode.summary: After hearing his fellow Crasher Squad members say they cannot fight alongside a Gishinian, Takeru takes off into space with Gaia. However, using Takeru’s absence on Earth as an opportunity to strike, the enemy attacks Earth. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 六神合体ができない!?
The Six gods: Unable to Combine ?
episode.summary: The Gishinians finally discover where the Six God robots are stationed. They attack Egypt where Sphinx, the body unit of God Mars, is located. The Crasher Squad is sent as reinforcement and a battle ensues. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 冥王星は地獄の星!
Pluto is the Planet of Hell !
episode.summary: A giant space fleet has left Earth to construct a base on Pluto and the Crasher Squad has been assigned to guard the fleet. However, Takeru hears a mysterious voice in his head urging him not to go to Pluto. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 爆破犯人はタケル!?
Is Takeru the Bomber ?!
episode.summary: Takeru bombs the Spaceport and a young boy, who admires Takeru, witnesses him in the act. With pictures to prove his guilt, Takeru is taken into custody. With Takeru out of the way, the Gishinians’ ships approach Earth. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: SOS! 東京沈没
SOS ! Tokyo is Sinking !
episode.summary: A massive earthquake triggers Tokyo to slowly sink. However, the earthquakes do not seem like a natural occurring earthquake. What is causing the earthquakes and can Takeru stop Tokyo from sinking beneath the sea? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 宇宙からきた少女!
The Girl From Space
episode.summary: Takeru and Namida head to the Space Control Center to secretly investigate the cause of the frequent collisions between spaceships. The Director of the Space Control Center and his granddaughter welcome them. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 謎の声はだれだ!?
Who`s Behind The Voice ?
episode.summary: A mysterious voice alerts Takeru that the Gishinians are plotting to assassinate the President. However, it was a trap laid out by Sagule, the Gishinian Spy Commander, in order to find out who is behind the mysterious voice. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 対決! マーズとマーグ
Showdown! Mars and Marg!
episode.summary: Marg is finally captured for treason and is ordered to kill Takeru in exchange for his life. Meanwhile, back at Battle Camp, Takeru receives a transmission from the mysterious voice, wishing to see him on Saturn. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 皇帝ズールをたおせ!
Defeat the Emperor Zule!
episode.summary: Marg is recaptured and taken back to Planet Gishin. A devastated Takeru chases after his brother, but the evil Emperor Zule appears and stands in his way. Faced with Emperor Zule’s invincible power, will Takeru be able to defeat Zule and get back Marg? Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 悲しき戦士・マーグ
Marg, the Sad Warrior!
episode.summary: Marg, whose memory has been erased by Emperor Zule, becomes a Gishinian Commander. His mission is to kill Takeru, the traitor. Meanwhile, back at Battle Camp on Earth, the Gishinian spies have taken Shizuko and Namida hostage. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 六神合体がくずれる!
Six God Combining Crash
episode.summary: Marg, who has been stationed at the frontline as a Gishinian Commander, launches a series of attacks on Earth’s major cities. Takeru fights the Gishinians with all this might. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: あやつり人形ミカ!
Mika: The Puppet
episode.summary: The moon base is under attack and the Crasher Squad is dispatched as reinforcement. Meanwhile, Lozé, Marg’s Lieutenant, infiltrates the moon base and takes over Mika’s body. Lozé begins sabotaging the base from the inside, but is found out by Takeru. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: アキラの恋人は女戦士
Akira`s Girlfriend is a Woman Warrior!
episode.summary: Takeru and Mika are shocked when they learn Akira has a new girlfriend. On his girlfriend’s request, Akira shows Akane around the base, but it’s all a trap. Once inside, Akane begins planting bombs throughout the base. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 南極はタケルの墓場だ!
The South Pole is Takeru`s Grave!
episode.summary: Takeru visits a secret base on the South Pole that’s researching the Warp Catapult. However, his visit is cut short when he learns that Battle Camp under attack by Marg. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: マーグ・地球に死す!
Marg Dies on Earth!
episode.summary: Takeru and Marg are locked in a fierce and decisive battle. During the battle, Marg regains his memories and their hearts connect once again. However, their reunion is short lived, as fate separates Takeru and Marg once again, this time forever. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 復しゅうに燃えろ!
The Call of Revenge!
episode.summary: In order to avenge Marg, Lozé takes Commissioner Otsuka and Shizuko hostage and challenges Takeru to a duel. To secure his mother and the Commissioner’s safety, Takeru accepts Lozé’s challenge. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: どれい惑星の対決!
Battle on the Slave Planet
episode.summary: Planet Gishin has taken control of an icy planet and the Crasher Squad is deployed to save its enslaved people. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: うらぎり者ロゼ!
Rosee, the Traitor
episode.summary: Touched by Takeru’s kindness, Lozé begins to doubt her reasons for serving Emperor Zule. A conflicted Lozé visits her home planet and is inadvertently captured by a guerrilla squad that is fighting the Gishinians. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 卑劣な皇帝ズール!!
The Despicable Emperor Zule
episode.summary: The Crasher Squad heads to Planet Gishin to negotiate a peace treaty with Emperor Zule. However, the Crasher Squad becomes engaged in a fierce battle against the Gishinian fighter squad. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 反陽子爆弾・バクハツ!?
Detonation of the Fusion Bomb
episode.summary: The Crasher Squad is caught in a space storm and makes an emergency landing on a planet disguised as Planet Gishin. Emperor Zule suddenly appears before the Crasher Squad and attacks them. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 新たな絆・別れ・出発!
New Worries, Separation, Departure!
episode.summary: The Crasher Squad finally lands on Planet Gishin. However, the evil Emperor Zule is determined to defeat Takeru, even if it means destroying Planet Gishin along with him. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 銀河へはじめての笑顔を
A Smile for the Galaxy
episode.summary: Emperor Zule’s warriors, the Gestalt Six, attack Takeru near the Hawaiian Islands. As proof Takeru did not defeat Emperor Zule, the Gestalt Six combine and a giant Zule appears before Takeru. The final battle between Zule and Takeru begins. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 危機を招く脱走者
The Dangerous Escapee
episode.summary: A month has past since the battle on Planet Gishin. The Crasher Squad, who has been newly assigned to Ceres Space Station, rescues a girl named Flore out in space. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: プラス対マイナスの運命
Plus Force vs. Minus Force
episode.summary: Flore, a negative Esper, shows nothing but intense animosity against Takeru, who is a positive Esper. Then, a ship from Planet Marmelo appears and demands they hand over Flore. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 謎の宇宙海賊船
The Unknown Pirate Ship
episode.summary: A mysterious pirate ship suddenly appears near the space station, as though they were guided by Flore’s telepathy. Gash, the pirate gang leader and his men infiltrate the space station. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: フローレの危険な仲間
Flore`s Allies
episode.summary: Takeru learns Flore is sending her telepathic messages to her fellow negative Espers, who escaped from Planet Marmelo before her. Gash, the pirate leader, appears with his pirate ship and claims Flore is their fellow comrade. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 一人ぼっちのフローレ
The Lonesome Flore
episode.summary: Flore leaves Ceres Space Station to determine if the people onboard the pirate ship are truly her comrades. She confirms Gash and his pirates are fellow negative Espers, but she can’t bring herself to join a ruthless band of pirates. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 宣戦布告
Proclamation of War
episode.summary: Flore finally opens up to the Crasher Squad and reveals the tragic fate of the negative Espers born on Planet Marmelo. Then, Ceres Space Station receives a transmission from Planet Marmelo. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 略奪されたフローレ
Flore Has Been Kidnapped!
episode.summary: Planet Marmelo declares war on Earth. Takeru and Flore are held responsible for the outbreak of war and are imprisoned. Meanwhile, the Marmelonian Forces begin an all out attack on Earth. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: タケル対ガッシュ!
Takeru vs Gash!
episode.summary: Gash tells a captive Flore the wretched life the negative Espers were subjected to by the positive Espers. Meanwhile, Takeru heads to space alone to rescue Flore. Led by Flore’s presence, Takeru and Gash come face to face on an asteroid belt. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: マーズ, 死ぬのは早い!
Mars, Your Time Has Come
episode.summary: The Cosmo Crasher is under attack by the Marmelonian Forces and Takeru is determined to save his friends. However, Takeru who is hit by the Brainwave Disrupter Rays is unable to combine the Six God robots. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: とらえられたタケル
Takeru is captured
episode.summary: The Earth Forces launch an attack on Gash’s pirate ship to take back Flore in hopes of handing her over to Planet Marmelo and thus ending the war. However, the Earth Forces are defeated and Takeru is taken captive during the battle. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 宇宙の墓場
The space graveyard
episode.summary: Flore heads to Planet Marmelo to find out if Gyron, the ruler of Planet Marmelo, is her father. However, she becomes lost in a dark nebula, known as the space cemetery. Takeru dives into the space cemetery to save Flore. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 母と娘のめぐりあい
Mother and daughter reunited
episode.summary: Takeru and Flore land on Planet Marmelo and with the help of Shikeel, Planet Marmelo’s spiritual leader, Flore is reunited with her mother, Armo. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 父, ギロンとの出会い
Meeting with my father, Gyron
episode.summary: Takeru and Flore head to the palace to see Gyron in order to convince him to stop the persecution of negative Espers and to stop the needless attacks on Earth. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 悲劇のタケル
Takeru`s tragedy
episode.summary: Upon his return to Earth, Takeru is suddenly dismissed from the Earth Defense Force. In despair, Takeru disappears along with God Mars. Shortly after, the Galilei Base is destroyed by God Mars. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: よみがえったマーグ
Marg returns
Yomigaetta Marg
episode.summary: Takeru tries to return to Earth, but is stopped by the Crasher Squad. The Earth Defense Forces were still under the impression that Takeru had destroyed the Galilei Base. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 宇宙にかける友情
Forging an alliance
Uchuu ni Kakeru Yuujou
episode.summary: Takeru joins the Crasher Squad once again after Naoto proved his innocence. Meanwhile, Gash and his pirate ship fleet leaves for Planet Marmelo, but come under attack by the Marmelonian Forces, which outnumber and outgun his ships. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 屍を越えて行け!
The field of corpses
episode.summary: Gash is determined to defeat Gyron, the ruler of Planet Marmelo and refuses the Crasher Squad’s help. Meanwhile, Gyron captures Shikeel, the spiritual leader of Planet Marmelo, who sides with the rebels, and prepares his execution to lure out Gash. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ガッシュの誤算
Gash`s decision
Gash no Gosan
episode.summary: Gash is determined to defeat Gyron, the ruler of Planet Marmelo and refuses the Crasher Squad’s help. Meanwhile, Gyron captures Shikeel, the spiritual leader of Planet Marmelo, who sides with the rebels, and prepares his execution to lure out Gash. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ガッシュ, 安らかに眠れ
Rest in peace, Gash
Gash, Yasuraka ni Nemure
episode.summary: Gash infiltrates the enemy base alone to save Mika, an uncharacteristic move for a man who is known for his ruthlessness. After rescuing Mika, the two escape on a snowmobile, but the enemy stands in their way. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ゴッドマーズが危ない!
God Mars is in danger!
episode.summary: Gyron orders the deployment of the powerful Magnetic Cannon to destroy God Mars. Kiel, the inventor of the Magnetic Cannon, adamantly opposes its use, as it will greatly alter Planet Marmelo’s geomagnetic field. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 地獄のマルメロ星
Hell on Marume
Jigoku no Marume Sei
episode.summary: Realizing God Mars will come undone, Takeru decides to attack the enemy base with the Six Robots separately. The Marmelonian Forces use the Magnetic Cannon to defeat Takeru once more, but are unable to keep up with Gaia’s speed. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 宿命! 親子の対決
Fate! Father and Daughter Battle!
episode.summary: Flore rushes to the palace to put an end to the battle against Gyron, her father. Realizing Planet Marmelo is on the brink of destruction, Gyron flees the palace while dodging Flore and Takeru’s attacks. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 危機せまるマルメロ星!
Crisis on Marume
episode.summary: Planet Marmelo’s destruction is now only a matter of time. When all hope seemed lost, its twin planet, the Planet of Death, had suddenly transformed into a habitable planet before their very eyes. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ギロン, 地球を狙う
Gyron`s Invasion of Earth
episode.summary: Gyron’s forces have entered the solar system and are quickly approaching Saturn. Kenji, who has been newly assigned as the Commander of the Earth Defense Force, battles against the enemy forces. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 迫る運命の対決!
The Fatal Encounter
episode.summary: The Earth Defense Forces are engaged in a battle against Gyron’s forces from invading Earth. Takeru and the Crasher Squad fight bravely, but the enemy succeeds in destroying Ceres Space Station. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ズール現る!
The Return of Zule
episode.summary: With Takeru’s help, Flore finally defeats Gyron. However, Flore hesitates to kill her father at the very last moment. Suddenly, a mysterious power kills Gyron. Thus, ending the war. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: タケルの命がない!?
Takeru`s Life is Ending?
episode.summary: The war against Gyron is finally over. Then one day, Lozé visits Earth. She is aware that Takeru is cursed with Zule’s Devil Rings and that his life is in danger. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 限られた命
Limited Life
episode.summary: Takeru is cursed with Zule’s Devil Rings, which drains his life force every time he uses his Esper powers. Meanwhile, a meteor lands in the Indian Ocean close to Titan, one of the God Mars robots. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 別離! タケルとロゼ
Farewell, Takeru and Rosee
episode.summary: Takeru and Lozé were visiting Marg’s grave in the South Pole when they receive word that Namida has gone missing. Namida was out on an expedition searching for UFOs in Greenland. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 炎の中にマーグを見た
Seeing Marg Through the Fire
episode.summary: Emperor Zule’s warriors burn the Amazon with their Esper Robots. Their plot is to suffocate the Earth by burning its rainforests. Takeru desperately tries to extinguish the wild fires while fighting Zule’s warriors. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 心の中の敵をくだけ!
Defeat the enemy in your heart
episode.summary: With death approaching, Takeru was feeling pressed about the possibility of not being able to defeat Zule and takes his frustration out on his fellow squad members. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: バラの騎士君は...!?
Rose Knight, where are you?
episode.summary: Zule plots to send a meteor crashing into Earth. The Crasher Squad heads to space to destroy the meteor but comes under attack. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 心のやすらぎは... いつに
When will peace of mind come?
episode.summary: Thinking only about the war against Zule, Takeru has forgotten what it’s like to have inner peace. Meanwhile, the enemy creates a massive sandstorm that reaches the stratosphere. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: ノアの反乱
Noah`s rebellion
episode.summary: Noah, the main computer that controls every aspect of the Earth Defense Force Headquarters is taken over by the enemy and begins wreaking havoc. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: タケル愛の奇蹟
Takeru, Miracle of Love
episode.summary: Shizuko learns Takeru does not have much longer to live. Taking advantage of Shizuko’s love for her son, Zule lures her to Angkor Wat in exchange for sparing Takeru’s life. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: タケル最後の誕生日?
Takeru`s final birthday?
episode.summary: Takeru collapses and is carried into the hospital after fighting the enemy on this eighteenth birthday. The Crasher Squad members are stunned when they finally learn the truth about Takeru’s condition. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 運命のバラの騎士
The Fate of the Rose Knight
episode.summary: Naoto and Namida were out investigating the deep ocean trenches lying east of Japan on a submarine when they come under attack. In order to save Naoto and Namida, Takeru fights the enemy but is pinned down by a massive robot that’s about to crush him. Source: crunchyroll

episode.title: 生きた愛した戦った
Life, Love and War
episode.summary: With Lozé’s help, Takeru realizes “the fiery planet that burns the sky” that Marg was referring to was the sun. It’s where Zule was holding Marg’s soul captive. Takeru dives into the sun and battles Zule, but the Devil Rings’ cruse stands in his way. Source: crunchyroll
